transcript:
Patient: I think my cultural background and family expectations play a big role in how I view my responsibilities as a caregiver. In my family, there's a strong emphasis on putting the needs of others before your own, especially when it comes to caring for elderly parents. I grew up watching my grandparents being cared for by my parents, and it was just expected that when the time came, I would do the same for my mother.

Therapist: That's a really important insight, Alexis. It's clear that your cultural background and family expectations have shaped your beliefs around caregiving and self-sacrifice. While these values can be admirable, they can also lead to feelings of guilt and burnout when taken to an extreme. It's okay to honor your cultural values while also recognizing the importance of self-care and setting boundaries. Let's explore this further. Can you think of a specific situation recently where you felt guilty for prioritizing your own needs over your mother's care?

Patient: Yes, just last week, I had planned to take an afternoon off to go for a hike, something I used to love doing but haven't had much time for lately. But when I told my mother about my plans, she made a comment about how she would be alone all afternoon and how much she misses our time together. I immediately felt guilty and ended up canceling my hike to stay with her, even though I really needed that time for myself.

Therapist: That's a great example, Alexis. Let's use this situation to practice reframing some of those guilty thoughts. What was going through your mind when your mother made that comment?

Patient: I thought, "I'm being selfish for wanting to take time for myself when my mother needs me. A good child would prioritize their parent's needs over their own."

Therapist: Okay, let's take a closer look at that thought. First, let's identify the cognitive distortion at play here. It seems like you might be engaging in "should" statements and all-or-nothing thinking. You're putting pressure on yourself to always prioritize your mother's needs, and you're seeing the situation as black or white – either you're a good child, or you're selfish. Does that resonate with you?

Patient: Yes, I can see that. I often think in those terms – I should do this, I must do that. And I do tend to see things as all or nothing, with no room for balance.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Alexis. Recognizing these cognitive distortions is an important step in reframing your thoughts. Now, let's look at the evidence for and against this thought. What evidence do you have that taking time for yourself means you're being selfish or a bad child?

Patient: Well, when I really think about it, I don't have much evidence to support that thought. I know that I'm a dedicated caregiver, and I spend a lot of time and energy caring for my mother. One afternoon off doesn't negate all of that.

Therapist: Exactly. And what evidence do you have against this thought? In what ways do you show up as a good child and caregiver, even when you take time for yourself?

Patient: I guess I show up as a good child and caregiver in many ways – I'm always there for my mother when she needs me, I make sure she has everything she needs, and I spend quality time with her whenever I can. Taking an afternoon off doesn't change any of that.

Therapist: That's right, Alexis. You can be both a loving, dedicated caregiver and someone who values and prioritizes their own well-being. Taking time for yourself doesn't mean you're being selfish or neglecting your mother. In fact, by taking care of yourself, you're actually better equipped to show up as the best version of yourself for your mother and other loved ones. With that in mind, let's come up with an alternative thought that feels more balanced and compassionate. What could you tell yourself in moments like these?

Patient: I could tell myself, "It's okay to take time for myself. Taking a break doesn't mean I'm being selfish or neglecting my mother. I can be a good child and caregiver while also prioritizing my own needs."

Therapist: That's a wonderful alternative thought, Alexis. It acknowledges the importance of self-care while also honoring your role as a caregiver. Now, let's think about how you can communicate your needs effectively with your mother and other family members. What do you think might help them understand your perspective?
